Definition.WordDefinition: Hoof a cleft hoof as of neat cattle (Ex. 10:26; Ezek. 32:13); hence also of the horse, though not cloven (Isa. 5:28). The "parting of the hoof" is one of the distinctions between clean and unclean animals (Lev. 11:3; Deut. 14:7).

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Hoof \Hoof\, v. i. 1. To walk as cattle. [R.] --William Scott. [1913 Webster]
2. To be on a tramp; to foot. [Slang, U.S.] [1913 Webster]
{To hoof it}, to foot it.
{On the hoof}, of cattle, standing (on the hoof); not slaughtered.
{beef on the hoof}, live cattle. [Webster 1913 Suppl.]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Hoof \Hoof\ (h[=oo]f), n.; pl. {Hoofs} (h[=oo]fs), very rarely {Hooves} (h[=oo]vz). [OE. hof, AS. h[=o]f; akin to D. hoef, G. huf, OHG. huof, Icel. h[=o]fr, Sw. hof, Dan. hov; cf. Russ. kopuito, Skr. [,c]apha. [root]225.] 1. The horny substance or case that covers or terminates the feet of certain animals, as horses, oxen, etc. [1913 Webster]
On burnished hooves his war horse trode. --Tennyson. [1913 Webster]
2. A hoofed animal; a beast. [1913 Webster]
Our cattle also shall go with us; there shall not a hoof be left behind. --Ex. x. 26. [1913 Webster]
3. (Geom.) See {Ungula}. [1913 Webster]

hoof n 1: the foot of an ungulate mammal 2: the horny covering of the end of the foot in hoofed mammals v 1: walk; "let's hoof it to the disco" [syn: {foot}, {leg it}, {hoof it}] 2: dance in a professional capacity [also: {hooves} (pl)]
